Sonali gautam@ 2 things to remember:
1. Correct order of module is: Educate, Organize, Agitate. That order is very very important, changing that order will be dangerous and can be counter-productive. Every Organization sud be leaded by education, and every Agitation sud be leaded by Organization. Education does not mean only college education, it also mean understanding and educating people about correct organization and agitation.
2. That module is a spiral one, not a linear. In simple language, first little education, little organization, little agitation. Then, little more education, little more organization, little more agitation. Thats way continue in increasing order of intensity. One sud not be stopped, but continuously striving for growth.
These two conditions are important for careful planning and risk management, and for continuous growth without having to wait indefinitely. Most difficult job is assessment of wat level of intensity & method is suitable at particular stage of spiral.
Wo log bahujano par humla karne aur baad me bhi apni hi chalane me kamyaab ho gaye. Wo isaliye ki agitation utna planned or organized nahi tha, aur wo isaliye nahi tha kyuki us mamle me jaruri chizo ki education ya assessment nahi kiya.

I am an Atheist. I do not believe in the existence of God. There is no testable evidence to support the belief in any gods or supernatural entities. I rely on science, reason, logic, and empirical evidence to form my worldview and have not found compelling evidence or arguments to support the existence of God. The universe is governed by natural laws and forces, rather than moral, spiritual, or supernatural ones. As an atheist, I reject religious dogma, supernaturalism, and superstition as the basis of morality and decision-making. I emphasize the social and empirical nature of inquiry and prioritize scientific solutions to intellectual problems. There is an intrinsic intellectual conflict between faith and science, and that it inevitably leads to hostility. I am engaged in a continually evolving search for truth, primarily through science and philosophy.

Now 8 years past. 
If people say India is Caste free then it is completely Wrong.
After this incident,some other incident also happened. And all of these incidents broke my faith in Hindu religion. TODAY, I don't believe in any religion. Now I Just believe in God. I Don't give the name of my God. I just talk to unknown power. that's our creator.

‚Äã OBCs were Shudras; SCs were outside the varna system (often called Ati-Shudras). Before the Gupta period, access to deities like Shiva and Vishnu was limited for lower castes. OBCs mainly followed folk or local forms like Krishna and Hanuman. OBCs worked in farming and crafts; SCs in leather, sanitation, and cremation. The Bhakti movement promoted caste-free devotion, and many lower castes also converted to Islam seeking dignity.

All the communities that are considered as "Untouchables/ Out-Caste" now, were enjoying very high status in the society, several centuries ago. Several centuries ago, when Aarya's brought "Varnashram" concept, a set of people who were in very high status in the society refused to accept it. So with the support of the then Kings, Aarya's asked that set of people to leave the villages and live outside the village. Then they asked them not to take water from the village ponds. After that they asked that set of people not to walk on the streets of the villages. And they asked Villagers not to talk/ mingle with that set of people who refused to accept "Varnashram Concept". And finally Aarya's announced that set of people  as "Untouchables/ Out-Caste" with support of the then Kings. We, the Scheduled Caste were in high status in the society several centuries ago. We have to regain our status now. Our Scheduled Caste population is 4 Crores in UP. With 4 Crore Vote, we can definitely decide who should form the Government. The Great Literary Mr.Valmiki wrote the Great Literature "Ramayan". But Valmiki community is aN Untouchable/ Out-Caste now. In Tamil Nadu, the Great Poet "Thiruvalluvar" wrote "Thirukural" But Thiruvalluvar's community "Paraiyar/ Pariah" is an Untouchable/ Out-Caste" now. May God bless the Scheduled Caste Communities and let us regain our high status once again now.

I am from the so-called 'lower caste' community. 
My question is this - Were my ancestors ever Hindus? 
- Hinduism is 5000 years old.
- Only after independence my ancestors were allowed to enter the temples.i.e. for the last 75 years. 
- That means for 4,925 years we were not allowed to¬† even walk near the temple premises, forget Worsh. 
- we had no benefits or life lessons taught to us from the scriptures. 

Example :¬† if there is a club in your town but you are not allowed to enter the club or¬† participate in the club activities, can you call yourself a member of that club???
It would be foolish of you to consider yourself a member of that club just because it is located in your town. 

Conclusion: My ancestors were never Hindus and your ancestors never considered them as Hindus.

There never was caste discrimination until the start of 1871 British Criminal Tribes bill who eventually became SC. Which society accepts criminals so they faced discrimination.

ST used to live in Forest with their own rules, culture, etc which ended with the British Forest Act 1865. Due to their different food habits sometimes considered strange and different behaviour which was also considered strange thus they faced discrimination.

Manusmriti is half. There is Diwij Sanskar in it too. Diwij means Twice birth. One is Jaati/Varn(fluid caste) in which he was born and second time he gets assigned to a new Varn/Jaati by the Guru's when he graduate from Gurukuls thus twice born.

Bhaarat had 95%-98% literacy till the British education act 1835. (Source:- Gandhi follower Dharmpal's book "a beautiful tree") when British left literacy was just 12%.


1835 British Education Act ended Gurukuls. Gurukul used to give free education as well as hostel facilities to all students. You can also read British Madras Presidency governor Thomas Munro's report. He surveyed Bhaarat's 6 lakh Gurukuls found 66% shudra(SC/dalit) varn studying free there. We had 2 lakhs women Gurukuls!   



Diwij Sanskar gave Shudra Kings in Bhaarat: 

Suheldev Pasi(SC Dalit) of Bharuch uttar pradesh, 

Santhar Pasi(SC Dalit) of Ramkot Uttar Pradesh, 

Utpala Chamar(SC Dalit) dynasty of Kashmir,

Koli(ST Dalit) dynasty of Ramnagar Gujarat,

Garha Katanga or Garha Mandla Kingdom of Jabalpur of Gond(ST Dalit) Dynasty, 

Chanda Kingdom of Chandrapur of Gond(ST Dalit) dynasty.

Kherla Kingdom of Betul of Gond(ST Dalit) Dynasty, 

Deogarh Kingdom of Nagpur and Chhindwara of Gond(ST Dalit) Dynasty,

Meena(ST) dynasty of Mewar Rajasthan, 

Meena(ST) Chand dynasty of Amber Rajasthan.... 

Ramchandra Karat(Shudra) of Orissa was a shudra.

The earliest application to the formal division into four social classes (without using the term¬†varna) appears in the late Rigvedic¬†Purusha Sukta¬†(RV 10.90.11‚Äì12), which has the Brahman, Rajanya (instead of Kshatriya), Vaishya and Shudra classes forming the mouth, arms, thighs and feet at the sacrifice of the primordial¬†Purusha, respectively:
When they divided Purusa how many portions did they make?
What do they call his mouth, his arms? What do they call his thighs and feet?
12. The Brahman was his mouth, of both his arms was the Rajanya made.
His thighs became the Vaishya, from his feet the Shudra was produced.

An Anecdote. In Odisha, entry into temples was prohibited not only for untouchables, but for other lower castes as well. A K Biswas has written about two events in Rabindranath Tagore‚Äôs life published in weekly Mainstream in 2010. The entry of the Tagores in the sacred shrine was officially banned. A law in this behalf was enacted by the British government in 1809. The last British Viceroy Lord Mountbatten had accompanied Dr BR Ambedkar and visited Puri. While the British Paramount received red carpet reception the priests denied Dr Ambedkar entry into the Jagannath temple.

The fundamental difference between the British rule and Independent India regarding temple entry for Dalits is that all laws enacted by the Britishers denying entry into the temples lapsed once the Indian Constitution was adopted with great vigor and fervor. But the rules of socially powerful class are still intact.
